results.title: The Raven
results.creator_credit: American International Pictures (AIP) and Roger Corman
results.brief_description: Loosely adapted from the classic poem by one of America’s most famous poets, Edgar Allan Poe, “The Raven” is a comedy-horror almost bordering on parody about a 16th century ‘good’ sorceror, Craven (Vincent Price), his presumed-dead wife Lenore (Hazel Court), the ‘evil’ sorceror Dr Scarabus (Boris Karloff), the Raven who is actually a magician by the name of Bedlo (Peter Lorre) and Bedlo’s son (a very young Jack Nicholson). This tale of sorcery, witchcraft and ‘evil’ versus ‘good’ is full of tongue-in-cheek humor with a gothic flavour. Screenplay by Richard Matheson and music by Les Baxter. Cast also includes Olive Sturgess, Connie Wallace, William Baskin, Aaron Saxon.

results.title: The Raven
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Carl Laemmle and Louis Friedlander
results.brief_description: A macabre horror classic from a story by Edgar Allen Poe, “The Raven” centres on a brilliant but unstable surgeon, Dr Richard Vollin (Bela Lugosi), with a morbid obsession for instruments of torture. When Jean Thatcher (Irene Ware), daughter of Judge Thatcher (Samuel S. Hinds) is injured in a car accident, it is Dr Vollin who steps in and saves her life. However, the beautiful Jean becomes frightened of Vollin’s increasing attraction and advances towards her and pleads to her father to ask Vollin to leave her alone. Vollin’s rejection turns to revenge when by chance, an escaped killer, Edmond Bateman (Boris Karloff), approaches the surgeon for a new face. Bateman unwittingly becomes a victim of Vollin’s sinister plan for the kidnap, torture and death of Jean and her fiance. This original version of “The Raven”, through its use of black and white cinematography, brings out the evil and horror in Poe’s classic tale - shadowy silhouettes, dark stormy nights, howling winds, flashes of lightning, hidden dungeons, torture chambers - all the necessary ingredients, plus the superb, if somewhat melodramatic, acting by the cast, particularly Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi. Cast also includes Lester Matthews, Inez Courtney, Spencer Charters, Ian Wolfe, Maidel Turner. Screenplay by David Boehm.

results.title: The Rats of Tobruk
results.creator_credit: Charles Chauvel Productions and Charles Chauvel
results.brief_description: Grant Taylor, Peter Finch and Chips Rafferty are cast as three bold Australians in the war-time-morale-boosting feature, recreating war-torn Tobruk in a field near Camden, NSW. Although ostensibly a tribute to the Australian fighting spirits, “The Rats of Tobruk” is dominated less by rhetorical patriotism that by a sense of tragedy and heartbreak of war. George Wallace and Joe Valli appear frequently throughout the film to improvise some comic relief but the mood remains set by the three heroes as they soberly face their responsibilities in the war.

results.title: The Rape of the earth
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “This Modern Age”.
This film puts squarely before its audience the seriousness of the question of world-wide misuse of the soil resources of the earth. Primitive peoples have not caused more devastation than civilised peoples; in fact, they have caused less, for civilised humans organises agricultural and pastoral activities on a greater scale.

results.title: The Ransom of red chief
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Marion Rosenberg and Tony Bill
results.brief_description: Based on the famous O. Henry short story, this humorous film captures the atmosphere of the 1920’s in its settings and spirited music score. Two shabby and inept con men think that kidnapping the banker’s son in a sleepy Alabama town and holding him for two thousand dollars ransom will be easy money. But young Johnny (Red Chief) drives them to distraction with his antics. Cutting short the kidnapping, they rush to the designated spot to pick up the money - only to find the tables again turned.

results.title: The Rainmakers
results.creator_credit: CSIRO, Division of Radiophysics, S.T. Evans and M. Graham
results.brief_description: Rainmaking up to recent times has been a mixture of speculation and superstition. From 1946, research and practical experiment have shown that man can induce rain. Shows the “cloud machine” in the CSIRO laboratories, and the first successful, though uneconomical method of seeding cloud with dry ice. The latest method, using silver iodide, is explained, and flights over the Snowy Mountains and Dividing Range, using this chemical, are made with good result.
